message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Towards the Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs): A Comprehensive Review
Paper Abstract: Recently, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), also known as drones, have come in a great diversity of several applications such as military, construction, image and video mapping, medical, search and rescue, parcel delivery, hidden area exploration, oil rigs and power line monitoring, precision farming, wireless communication and aerial surveillance. The drone industry has been getting significant attention as a model of manufacturing, service and delivery convergence, introducing synergy with the coexistence of different emerging domains. UAVs offer implicit peculiarities such as increased airborne time and payload capabilities, swift mobility, and access to remote and disaster areas. Despite these potential features, including extensive variety of usage, high maneuverability, and cost-efficiency, drones are still limited in terms of battery endurance, flight autonomy and constrained flight time to perform persistent missions. Other critical concerns are battery endurance and the weight of drones, which must be kept low. Intuitively it is not suggested to load them with heavy batteries. This study highlights the importance of drones, goals and functionality problems. In this review, a comprehensive study on UAVs, swarms, types, classification, charging, and standardization is presented. In particular, UAV applications, challenges, and security issues are explored in the light of recent research studies and development. Finally, this review identifies the research gap and presents future research directions regarding UAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about wireless communication:

## Definition

Wireless communication is the transfer of information (telecommunication) between two or more points without the use of an electrical conductor, optical fiber or other continuous guided medium for the transfer.

## Common Technologies

Modern wireless technologies include mobile broadband, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth. Additionally, IEEE 802.11 defines a common flavor of open-standards wireless radio-wave technology known as Wi-Fi.

## Applications

Wireless operations permit services, such as mobile and interplanetary communications, that are impossible or impractical to implement with the use of wires.(no content)A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.

## Historical Context

The term wireless was initially used from about 1890 for the first radio transmitting and receiving technology, as in wireless telegraphy, until the new word radio replaced it around 1920.(no content)In 1894, Guglielmo Marconi began developing a wireless telegraph system using radio waves, and Marconi and Karl Ferdinand Braun were awarded the 1909 Nobel Prize for Physics for their contribution to this form of wireless telegraphy.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Wireless communication systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Wireless_communication_systems"},{"title":"Wireless - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless"},{"title":"Wireless Personal Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_Personal_Communications"},{"title":"Wireless Communications Service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_Communications_Service"},{"title":"IEEE Wireless Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IEEE_Wireless_Communications"},{"title":"Wireless Communications Transfer Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_Communications_Transfer_Protocol"},{"title":"List of American wireless communication service providers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_American_wireless_communication_service_providers"},{"title":"Aironet Wireless Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aironet_Wireless_Communications"},{"title":"Weightless (wireless communications) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weightless_(wireless_communications)"},{"title":"Wireless network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wireless_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about wireless communication:

## Definition

Wireless communication is the transfer of information (telecommunication) between two or more points without the use of an electrical conductor, optical fiber or other continuous guided medium for the transfer.

## Common Technologies

Modern wireless technologies include mobile broadband, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth. Additionally, IEEE 802.11 defines a common flavor of open-standards wireless radio-wave technology known as Wi-Fi.

## Applications

Wireless operations permit services, such as mobile and interplanetary communications, that are impossible or impractical to implement with the use of wires.(no content)A wireless network is a computer network that uses wireless data connections between network nodes.

## Historical Context

The term wireless was initially used from about 1890 for the first radio transmitting and receiving technology, as in wireless telegraphy, until the new word radio replaced it around 1920.(no content)In 1894, Guglielmo Marconi began developing a wireless telegraph system using radio waves, and Marconi and Karl Ferdinand Braun were awarded the 1909 Nobel Prize for Physics for their contribution to this form of wireless telegraphy.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Swarm robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

## Swarm Robotics

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)They take inspiration from nature, including collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature such as honey bee aggregation.

### Key Characteristics

Swarm robotics emphasizes that robots are autonomous, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.(no content)Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.(no content)Miniaturization is also key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach to achieve meaningful behavior at swarm-level.

### History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005.

### Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely, to explore the unknown environment and solve complex mazes via onboard sensors.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures and components.

Links: [{"title":"Surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance"},{"title":"Surveillance tools - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_tools"},{"title":"Mass surveillance industry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_surveillance_industry"},{"title":"Center on Privacy and Technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_on_Privacy_and_Technology"},{"title":"Computer surveillance in the workplace - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_surveillance_in_the_workplace"},{"title":"Techno-authoritarianism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IT-backed_authoritarianism"},{"title":"Biometrics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biometrics"},{"title":"NSO Group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NSO_Group"},{"title":"Edward Snowden - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edward_Snowden"},{"title":"Anti-facial recognition mask - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-facial_recognition_mask"}]

I've completed a web search for "Surveillance technology." Here's an overview of the key findings:

## Types of Surveillance Technology

Surveillance tools are all means of technology provided and used by the surveillance industry, police or military intelligence, and national security institutions that enable individual surveillance and mass surveillance.

### Biometric Surveillance

Biometric surveillance is a technology that measures and analyzes human physical and/or behavioral characteristics for authentication, identification, or screening purposes.(no content)Examples of physical characteristics include fingerprints, DNA, and facial patterns.

### Video Surveillance

As of 2016, there are about 350 million surveillance cameras worldwide. About 65% of these cameras are installed in Asia.

### Computer and Internet Surveillance

The vast majority of computer surveillance involves the monitoring of data and traffic on the Internet.(no content)Computer surveillance in the workplace is the use of computers to monitor activity in a workplace. Computer monitoring is a method of collecting performance data which employers obtain through digitalised employee monitoring.

### Government Programs

The NSA runs a program known as PRISM, which is a data mining system that gives the United States government direct access to information from technology companies. Through accessing this information, the government is able to obtain search history, emails, stored information, live chats, file transfers, and more.

## Industry and Growth

The mass surveillance industry is a multibillion-dollar industry that has undergone phenomenal growth since 2001. According to data provided by The Wall Street Journal, the retail market for surveillance tools has grown from "nearly zero" in 2001 to about US$5 billion in 2011.

## Concerns

Surveillance can unjustifiably violate people's privacy and is often criticized by civil liberties activists.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about drone aircraft:

## Definition and Overview

A drone, or unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)In common usage, "drone" is often applied to both military and civilian UAVs, while technical and regulatory documents may prefer terms such as UAV, UAS, RPAS, or uncrewed aircraft.

## Historical Background

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)The term drone has been used from the early days of aviation, some being applied to remotely flown target aircraft used for practice firing of a battleship's guns, such as the 1920s Fairey Queen and 1930s de Havilland Queen Bee.

## Types of Drones

**Combat Drones:** An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV), also known as a combat drone, fighter drone or battlefield UAV, is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs on hardpoints or within weapons bay, allowing it to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

**Civilian Uses:** Firefighters, police, miners, and weather researchers are now using UAVs (commonly referred to as drones), which were first used in military sectors.

## Autonomy and Control

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

## Technology and Capabilities

In addition to the software, autonomous drones also employ a host of advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about drone aircraft:

## Definition and Overview

A drone, or unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)In common usage, "drone" is often applied to both military and civilian UAVs, while technical and regulatory documents may prefer terms such as UAV, UAS, RPAS, or uncrewed aircraft.

## Historical Background

UAVs were originally developed through the twentieth century for military missions.(no content)The term drone has been used from the early days of aviation, some being applied to remotely flown target aircraft used for practice firing of a battleship's guns, such as the 1920s Fairey Queen and 1930s de Havilland Queen Bee.

## Types of Drones

**Combat Drones:** An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV), also known as a combat drone, fighter drone or battlefield UAV, is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs on hardpoints or within weapons bay, allowing it to perform tactical attacks known as drone strikes.

**Civilian Uses:** Firefighters, police, miners, and weather researchers are now using UAVs (commonly referred to as drones), which were first used in military sectors.

## Autonomy and Control

The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

## Technology and Capabilities

In addition to the software, autonomous drones also employ a host of advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

Here's comprehensive information about Unmanned Aerial Vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)UAVs include both autonomous drones (capable of operating without human input) and remotely piloted vehicles (RPVs), and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight and are powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with Austrian forces besieging Venice attempting to launch incendiary balloons at the city.(no content)The Spanish engineer Leonardo Torres Quevedo introduced a radio-based control-system called the Telekino at the Paris Academy of Science in 1903, as a way of testing airships without risking human life.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, which was an entry-level drone and is considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications. These include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions, and detection of illegal hunting.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
